# FA Cup

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For other uses, see [FA Cup (disambiguation)](/wiki/FA_Cup_\(disambiguation\)
"FA Cup \(disambiguation\)").

FA Cup
[![upright={{{upright}}}](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Fa_cup.svg/200px-
Fa_cup.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Fa_cup.svg "upright={{{upright}}}")

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Soccerball_current_event.svg/33px-
Soccerball_current_event.svg.png) _[2017–18 FA
Cup](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_FA_Cup "2017–18 FA Cup")_  
  
**The FA Cup** , known officially as **The Football Association Challenge
Cup** , is an annual [knockout](/wiki/Single-elimination_tournament "Single-
elimination tournament") [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association
football") competition in men's domestic [English
football](/wiki/Football_in_England "Football in England"). First played
during the [1871–72 season](/wiki/1871%E2%80%9372_FA_Cup "1871–72 FA Cup"), it
is the [oldest association football
competition](/wiki/Oldest_football_competitions "Oldest football
competitions") in the world.[1] It is organised by and named after [The
Football Association](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football
Association") (The FA). For sponsorship reasons, from 2015 through to 2018 it
is also known as **The Emirates FA Cup**. A concurrent
[women's](/wiki/Women%27s_association_football "Women's association football")
tournament is also held, the [FA Women's Cup](/wiki/FA_Women%27s_Cup "FA
Women's Cup").

The competition is open to any eligible [club](/wiki/Football_club "Football
club") down to Level 10 of the [English football league
system](/wiki/English_football_league_system "English football league system")
– all 92 professional clubs in the [Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League
"Premier League") (Level 1) and the [English Football
League](/wiki/English_Football_League "English Football League") (Levels 2 to
4), and several hundred "non-league" teams in Steps 1 to 6 of the [National
League System](/wiki/National_League_System "National League System") (Levels
5 to 10).[2] A record 763 clubs competed in
[2011–12](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_FA_Cup "2011–12 FA Cup"). The tournament
consists of 12 randomly drawn rounds followed by [the semi-
finals](/wiki/FA_Cup_semi-finals "FA Cup semi-finals") and [the
final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final"). Entrants are not
[seeded](/wiki/Seed_\(sports\) "Seed \(sports\)"), although a system of
[byes](/wiki/Bye_\(sports\) "Bye \(sports\)") based on league level ensures
higher ranked teams enter in later rounds – the minimum number of games needed
to win the competition ranges from six to fourteen.

The first six rounds are the Qualifying Competition, from which 32 teams
progress to the first round of the Competition Proper, meeting the first of
the 48 professional teams from [Leagues One](/wiki/EFL_League_One "EFL League
One") and [Two](/wiki/EFL_League_Two "EFL League Two"). The last entrants are
the Premier League and [Championship](/wiki/EFL_Championship "EFL
Championship") clubs, into the draw for the Third Round Proper.[2] In the
modern era, only one non-league team has ever reached the quarter-finals, and
teams below Level 2 have never reached the final.[note 1] As a result, as well
as who wins, significant focus is given to those
"[minnows](/wiki/Underdog_\(competition\) "Underdog \(competition\)")"
(smaller teams) who progress furthest, especially if they achieve an unlikely
"giant-killing" victory.

Winners receive the FA Cup trophy, of which there have been two designs and
five actual cups; the latest is a 2014 replica of the second design,
introduced in 1911. Winners also qualify for [the Europa
League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League") and a place in the [FA
Community Shield](/wiki/FA_Community_Shield "FA Community Shield") match.
[Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.") are the current holders, having
beaten [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.") 2–1 in the [2017
final](/wiki/2017_FA_Cup_Final "2017 FA Cup Final") to win the cup for the
13th time in their history and become the tournament's most successful club.
Arsenal's [Arsène Wenger](/wiki/Ars%C3%A8ne_Wenger "Arsène Wenger") is the
most successful manager in the competition with seven finals won.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

See also: [History of the FA Cup](/wiki/History_of_the_FA_Cup "History of the
FA Cup")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/FACupFinal1905NewcastleVilla.jpg/250px-
FACupFinal1905NewcastleVilla.jpg)](/wiki/File:FACupFinal1905NewcastleVilla.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FACupFinal1905NewcastleVilla.jpg "Enlarge")

[Harry Hampton](/wiki/Harry_Hampton_\(footballer,_born_1885\) "Harry Hampton
\(footballer, born 1885\)") scores one of his two goals in the [1905 FA Cup
Final](/wiki/1905_FA_Cup_Final "1905 FA Cup Final") where [Aston
Villa](/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C. "Aston Villa F.C.") defeated [Newcastle
United](/wiki/Newcastle_United_F.C. "Newcastle United F.C.")

In 1863, the newly founded [Football
Association](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football Association") (the
FA) published the [Laws of the
Game](/wiki/Laws_of_the_Game_\(association_football\) "Laws of the Game
\(association football\)") of Association Football, unifying the various
different rules in use before then. On 20 July 1871, in the offices of [_The
Sportsman_ newspaper](/wiki/The_Sportsman_\(1865_newspaper\) "The Sportsman
\(1865 newspaper\)"), the FA Secretary [C. W. Alcock](/wiki/C._W._Alcock "C.
W. Alcock") proposed to the FA committee that "it is desirable that a
Challenge Cup should be established in connection with the Association for
which all clubs belonging to the Association should be invited to compete".
The [inaugural FA Cup tournament](/wiki/1871%E2%80%9372_FA_Cup "1871–72 FA
Cup") kicked off in November 1871. After thirteen games in all,
[Wanderers](/wiki/Wanderers_F.C. "Wanderers F.C.") were crowned the winners in
the final, on 16 March 1872. Wanderers retained the trophy the following year.
The modern cup was beginning to be established by the 1888–89 season, when
qualifying rounds were introduced.[3]

Following the [1914–15](/wiki/1914%E2%80%9315_FA_Cup "1914–15 FA Cup")
edition, the competition was suspended due to the [First World
War](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), and did not resume until
[1919–20](/wiki/1919%E2%80%9320_FA_Cup "1919–20 FA Cup"). The
[1922–23](/wiki/1922%E2%80%9323_FA_Cup "1922–23 FA Cup") competition saw the
first final to be played in the newly opened [Wembley
Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\) "Wembley Stadium \(1923\)") (known at
the time as the Empire Stadium). Due to the outbreak of [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the competition was not played between
the [1938–39](/wiki/1938%E2%80%9339_FA_Cup "1938–39 FA Cup") and
[1945–46](/wiki/1945%E2%80%9346_FA_Cup "1945–46 FA Cup") editions. Due to the
wartime breaks, the competition did not celebrate its centenary year until
[1980–81](/wiki/1980%E2%80%9381_FA_Cup "1980–81 FA Cup"); fittingly the final
featured a goal by [Ricky Villa](/wiki/Ricky_Villa "Ricky Villa") which was
later voted the greatest goal ever scored at Wembley Stadium, but has since
been replaced by [Steven Gerrard](/wiki/Steven_Gerrard "Steven Gerrard").[4]

Having previously featured replays, the modern day practice of ensuring the
semi-final and final matches finish on the day, was introduced from 2000
onwards. Redevelopment of Wembley saw the final played outside of England for
the first time, the 2001–2006 finals being played at the [Millennium
Stadium](/wiki/Millennium_Stadium "Millennium Stadium") in
[Cardiff](/wiki/Cardiff "Cardiff"). The final returned to Wembley in 2007,
followed by the semi-finals from 2008.

## Eligibility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Eligibility")]

The competition is open to any club down to Level 10 of the [English football
league system](/wiki/English_football_league_system "English football league
system") which meets the eligibility criteria. All clubs in the top four
levels (the [Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") and the
three divisions of the [Football League](/wiki/The_Football_League "The
Football League")) are automatically eligible. Clubs in the next six levels
([non-league football](/wiki/Non-league_football "Non-league football")) are
also eligible provided they have played in either the FA Cup, [FA
Trophy](/wiki/FA_Trophy "FA Trophy") or [FA Vase](/wiki/FA_Vase "FA Vase")
competitions in the previous season. Newly formed clubs, such as [F.C. United
of Manchester](/wiki/F.C._United_of_Manchester "F.C. United of Manchester") in
[2005–06](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_FA_Cup "2005–06 FA Cup") and also
[2006–07](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_FA_Cup "2006–07 FA Cup"), may not therefore
play in the FA Cup in their first season. All clubs entering the competition
must also have a suitable stadium.

It is very rare for top clubs to miss the competition, although it can happen
in exceptional circumstances. [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C.
"Manchester United F.C.") did not defend their title in
[1999–2000](/wiki/1999%E2%80%932000_FA_Cup "1999–2000 FA Cup"), as they were
already in the [inaugural](/wiki/2000_FIFA_Club_World_Championship "2000 FIFA
Club World Championship") [Club World Championship](/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup
"FIFA Club World Cup"). The club stated that entering both tournaments would
overload their fixture schedule and make it more difficult to defend their
Champions League and Premier League titles. The club claimed that they did not
want to devalue the FA Cup by fielding a weaker side. The move benefited
United as they received a two-week break and won the 1999–2000 league title by
an 18-point margin, although they did not progress past the group stage of the
Club World Championship. The withdrawal from the FA Cup, however, drew
considerable criticism as this weakened the tournament's prestige and [Sir
Alex Ferguson](/wiki/Alex_Ferguson "Alex Ferguson") later admitted his regret
regarding their handling of the situation.[5][6][7]

Welsh sides that play in English leagues are eligible, although since the
creation of the [League of Wales](/wiki/Welsh_Premier_League "Welsh Premier
League") there are only six clubs remaining: [Cardiff
City](/wiki/Cardiff_City_F.C. "Cardiff City F.C.") (the only non-English team
to win the tournament, in [1927](/wiki/1927_FA_Cup_Final "1927 FA Cup
Final")), [Swansea City](/wiki/Swansea_City_A.F.C. "Swansea City A.F.C."),
[Newport County](/wiki/Newport_County_A.F.C. "Newport County A.F.C."),
[Wrexham](/wiki/Wrexham_F.C. "Wrexham F.C."), [Merthyr
Town](/wiki/Merthyr_Town_F.C. "Merthyr Town F.C.") and [Colwyn
Bay](/wiki/Colwyn_Bay_F.C. "Colwyn Bay F.C."). In the early years other teams
from Wales, Ireland and Scotland also took part in the competition, with
Glasgow side [Queen's Park](/wiki/Queen%27s_Park_F.C. "Queen's Park F.C.")
losing the final to [Blackburn Rovers](/wiki/Blackburn_Rovers "Blackburn
Rovers") in [1884](/wiki/1884_FA_Cup_Final "1884 FA Cup Final") and
[1885](/wiki/1885_FA_Cup_Final "1885 FA Cup Final") before being barred from
entering by the [Scottish Football
Association](/wiki/Scottish_Football_Association "Scottish Football
Association"). In the 2013–14 season the first [Channel
Island](/wiki/Channel_Islands "Channel Islands") club entered the competition
when [Guernsey F.C.](/wiki/Guernsey_F.C. "Guernsey F.C.") competed for the
first time.[8]

The number of entrants has increased greatly in recent years. In the
[2004–05](/wiki/FA_Cup_2004%E2%80%9305 "FA Cup 2004–05") season, 660 clubs
entered the competition, beating the long-standing record of 656 from the
1921–22 season. In [2005–06](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_FA_Cup "2005–06 FA Cup")
this increased to 674 entrants, in [2006–07](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_FA_Cup
"2006–07 FA Cup") to 687, in [2007–08](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_FA_Cup "2007–08
FA Cup") to 731 clubs, and for the [2008–09](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_FA_Cup
"2008–09 FA Cup") and [2009–10](/wiki/2009%E2%80%9310_FA_Cup "2009–10 FA Cup")
competitions it reached 762.[9] The number has varied slightly but remained
roughly stable since then, with 759 clubs participating in
[2010–11](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_FA_Cup "2010–11 FA Cup"), a record 763 in
[2011–12](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_FA_Cup "2011–12 FA Cup"), 758 for
[2012–13](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_FA_Cup "2012–13 FA Cup"), 737 for
[2013–14](/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_FA_Cup "2013–14 FA Cup") and 736 for
[2014–15](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_FA_Cup "2014–15 FA Cup"). By comparison, the
other major English domestic cup, the [League Cup](/wiki/EFL_Cup "EFL Cup"),
involves only the 92 members of the Premier League and Football League.

## Competition format[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Competition format")]

### Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Overview")]

Beginning in August, the competition proceeds as a [knockout
tournament](/wiki/Knockout_tournament "Knockout tournament") throughout,
consisting of twelve rounds, a semi-final and then a final, in May. A system
of byes ensures clubs above Level 9 and 10 enter the competition at later
stages. There is no [seeding](/wiki/Seed_\(tennis\) "Seed \(tennis\)"), the
fixtures in each round being determined by a random draw. Prior to the
quarter-finals, fixtures ending in a tie are replayed once only.[10] The first
six rounds are qualifiers, with the draws organised on a regional basis. The
next six rounds are the "proper" rounds where all clubs are in one draw.

### Schedule[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Schedule")]

Entrants from the bottom two levels (9 and 10) begin the competition in the
Extra Preliminary Round. Clubs from higher levels are then added in later
rounds, as per the table below. The months in which rounds are played are
traditional, with exact dates subject to each year's calendar.

Round[2] | New entrants at this round[2] | Month | No of matches  
---|---|---|---  
**Qualifying Competition**[2]  
Extra-Preliminary Round | Level 9 and 10 clubs | August | 184  
Preliminary Round | Level 8 clubs | 160  
First Round | Level 7 clubs | September | 116  
Second Round | Level 6 clubs | 80  
Third Round | none | October | 40  
Fourth Round | Level 5 clubs | 32  
**Competition Proper**[2]  
First Round | Level 3 and 4 clubs | November | 40  
Second Round | none | December | 20  
Third Round | Level 1 and 2 clubs | January | 32  
Fourth Round | none | 16  
Fifth Round | February | 8  
Quarter-finals | March | 4  
Semi-Finals | April | 2  
Final | May | 1  
  
The qualifying rounds are regionalised to reduce the travel costs for smaller
non-league sides. The first and second proper rounds were also previously
split into Northern and Southern sections, but this practice was ended after
the 1997–98 competition.

The final is normally held the Saturday after the [Premier
League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") season finishes in May. The
only seasons in recent times when this pattern was not followed were
[1999–2000](/wiki/1999%E2%80%932000_in_English_football "1999–2000 in English
football"), when most rounds were played a few weeks earlier than normal as an
experiment, and [2010–11](/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_in_English_football "2010–11
in English football") and [2012–13](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_in_English_football
"2012–13 in English football") when the FA Cup Final was played before the
Premier League season had finished, to allow [Wembley
Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium") to be ready for the [UEFA
Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League")
final,[11] as well as in [2011–12](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_in_English_football
"2011–12 in English football") to allow England time to prepare for that
summer's [European Championships](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012").[12]

### The draw[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: The draw")]

The draws for the Extra-Preliminary, Preliminary, and First Qualifying Rounds
used to all occur at the same time. Thereafter, the draw for each subsequent
round is not made until after the scheduled dates for the previous round,
meaning that in the case of replays, clubs will often know their future
opponents in advance. This season 2016/17 the draw for the 1st qualifying
round was drawn at a later date as per previous season's later rounds.

The draw for each of the proper rounds is broadcast live on television,
usually taking place at the conclusion of live coverage of one of the games of
the previous round. Public interest is particularly high during the draw for
the third round, which is where the top-ranked teams are added to the draw.

### Tiebreaking[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Tiebreaking")]

In rounds up to and including the fifth round proper, fixtures resulting in a
draw (after normal time) go to a [replay](/wiki/Replay_\(sports\) "Replay
\(sports\)"), played at the venue of the away team, at a later date; if that
replay is still tied, the winner is settled by a period of [extra
time](/wiki/Overtime_\(sports\) "Overtime \(sports\)"), and if still
necessary, a [penalty shootout](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-
out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-out \(association football\)").
Since [2016–17](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_FA_Cup "2016–17 FA Cup"), ties are
settled on the day from the quarter-finals onwards, using extra time and
penalties.

Until [1990–91](/wiki/1990%E2%80%9391_FA_Cup "1990–91 FA Cup"), further
replays would be played until one team was victorious. Some ties took as many
as six matches to settle; in their 1975 campaign, [Fulham](/wiki/Fulham_F.C.
"Fulham F.C.") played a total of 12 games over six rounds, which remains the
most games played by a team to reach a final.[13] Replays were traditionally
played three or four days after the original game, but from
[1991–92](/wiki/1991%E2%80%9392_FA_Cup "1991–92 FA Cup") they were staged at
least 10 days later on police advice for the rounds proper. This led to
[penalty shoot-outs](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty
shoot-out \(association football\)") being introduced, the first of which came
on 26 November 1991 when [Rotherham United](/wiki/Rotherham_United_F.C.
"Rotherham United F.C.") eliminated [Scunthorpe
United](/wiki/Scunthorpe_United_F.C. "Scunthorpe United F.C.").[14]

From [1980–81](/wiki/1980%E2%80%9381_FA_Cup "1980–81 FA Cup") to
[1998–99](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_FA_Cup "1998–99 FA Cup"), the [semi-
finals](/wiki/FA_Cup_semi-finals "FA Cup semi-finals") went to extra time on
the day if the score after 90 minutes was a draw. If the score was still level
after extra time, the match would go to a replay. Replays for the semi-finals
were scrapped for [1999–2000](/wiki/1999%E2%80%932000_FA_Cup "1999–2000 FA
Cup"), the last semi-final to go into a replay was in 1998–99 when Manchester
United beat Arsenal 2–1 after extra time. The first game had ended in a 0–0
draw.

The first [FA Cup Final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final") to go to extra
time and a replay was the [1875 final](/wiki/1875_FA_Cup_Final "1875 FA Cup
Final"), between the [Royal Engineers](/wiki/Royal_Engineers_A.F.C. "Royal
Engineers A.F.C.") and the [Old Etonians](/wiki/Old_Etonians_F.C. "Old
Etonians F.C."). The initial tie finished 1–1 but the Royal Engineers won the
replay 2–0 in normal time. The last replayed final was the [1993 FA Cup
Final](/wiki/1993_FA_Cup_Final "1993 FA Cup Final"), when Arsenal and
[Sheffield Wednesday](/wiki/Sheffield_Wednesday_F.C. "Sheffield Wednesday
F.C.") fought a 1–1 draw. The replay saw Arsenal win the FA Cup, 2–1 after
extra time.

The last quarter-final to go to a replay was Manchester United vs [West Ham
United](/wiki/West_Ham_United_F.C. "West Ham United F.C.") in the [2015–16 FA
Cup](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_FA_Cup "2015–16 FA Cup"). The original game at Old
Trafford ended in a 1–1 draw, while Manchester United won the replay at the
[Boleyn Ground](/wiki/Boleyn_Ground "Boleyn Ground"), 2–1. It was also the
last FA Cup game ever played at the Boleyn Ground.[15]

## Qualification for subsequent
competitions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Qualification for subsequent competitions")]

### European football[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: European football")]

The FA Cup winners qualify for the following season's [UEFA Europa
League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League") (formerly named the
UEFA Cup; from its launch in 1960 until 1998, they entered the now-defunct
[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup")
instead). This European place applies even if the team is relegated or is not
in the English top flight. In the past, if the FA Cup winning team also
qualified for the following season's [Champions
League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") or Europa League
through their league position, then the losing FA Cup finalist were given this
European berth instead. FA Cup winners enter the Europa League at the group
stage. Losing finalists, if they haven't qualified for Europe via the league,
began earlier, at the play-off or third qualifying round stage.[16] From the
[2015–16 UEFA Europa League](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_UEFA_Europa_League "2015–16
UEFA Europa League") season, however, [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") does not allow
the runners-up to qualify for the Europa League through the competition.[17]
If the winner – and until 2015, the runner-up – has already qualified for
Europe through their league position (with the exception of the UEFA Cup until
1998), the FA Cup berth is then given to the highest-place team in the league
who has not yet qualified.

### FA Community
Shield[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section:
FA Community Shield")]

The FA Cup winners also qualify for the following season's single-match [FA
Community Shield](/wiki/FA_Community_Shield "FA Community Shield"), the
traditional season opener played against the previous season's [Premier
League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") champions (or the Premier
League runners-up if the FA Cup winners also won the league – the
[double](/wiki/Double_\(association_football\)#England "Double \(association
football\)")).

## Venues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Venues")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/England_mai_2007_040.jpg/220px-
England_mai_2007_040.jpg)](/wiki/File:England_mai_2007_040.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:England_mai_2007_040.jpg "Enlarge")

Since 2007 the [FA Cup Final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final") has been held
at [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium"), on the site of
[the previous stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\) "Wembley Stadium
\(1923\)") which hosted it from 1923 to 2000.

Fixtures in the 12 rounds of the competition are usually played at the home
ground of one of the two teams. The [semi-finals](/wiki/FA_Cup_semi-finals "FA
Cup semi-finals") and [final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final") are played at
a neutral venue – the rebuilt [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley
Stadium") (since [2008](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_FA_Cup "2007–08 FA Cup") and
[2007](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_FA_Cup "2006–07 FA Cup") respectively).

### Competition rounds[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Competition rounds")]

In the matches for the twelve competition rounds, the team who plays at home
is decided when the fixtures are drawn – simply the first team drawn out for
each fixture. Occasionally games may have to be moved to other grounds due to
other events taking place, security reasons or a ground not being suitable to
host popular teams. In the event of a [draw](/wiki/Draw_\(tie\) "Draw
\(tie\)"), the [replay](/wiki/Replay_\(sports\) "Replay \(sports\)") is played
at the ground of the team who originally played [away from
home](/wiki/Home_advantage "Home advantage").

In the days when multiple replays were possible, the second replay (and any
further replays) were played at neutral grounds. The clubs involved could
alternatively agree to toss for home advantage in the second replay.

### Semi-finals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Semi-finals")]

The semi-finals have been played exclusively at the rebuilt [Wembley
Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium") since
[2008](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_FA_Cup "2007–08 FA Cup"), one year after it
opened and after it had already hosted a final (in 2007). For the first decade
of the competition, the [Kennington Oval](/wiki/The_Oval "The Oval") was used
as the semi-final venue. In the period between this first decade and the
reopening of Wembley, semi-finals were played at high-capacity neutral venues
around England; usually the home grounds of teams not involved in that semi-
final, chosen to be roughly equidistant between the two teams for fairness of
travel. The top three most used venues in this period were [Villa
Park](/wiki/Villa_Park "Villa Park") in Birmingham (55 times),
[Hillsborough](/wiki/Hillsborough_Stadium "Hillsborough Stadium") in Sheffield
(34 times) and [Old Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford "Old Trafford") in Manchester
(23 times). The [original Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\)
"Wembley Stadium \(1923\)") was also used seven times for semi-final, between
1991 and 2000 (the last held there), but not always for fixtures featuring
London teams. In 2005, both were held at the Millennium Stadium.

In 2003 the FA took the decision to permanently use the new Wembley for semi-
finals to recoup debts in financing the new stadium.[18] This was
controversial, with the move seen as both unfair to fans of teams located far
from London, as well as taking some of the prestige away from a Wembley
final.[19] In defending the move, the FA has also cited the extra capacity
Wembley offers, although the 2013 fixture between Millwall and Wigan led to
the unprecedented step of placing 6,000 tickets on sale to neutral fans after
the game failed to sell out.[20] A fan poll by _[The
Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_ in 2013 found 86% opposition to
Wembley semi-finals.[20]

### Final[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Final")]

The final has been played at the rebuilt [Wembley
Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium") since it opened, in
[2007.](/wiki/2006%E2%80%9307_FA_Cup "2006–07 FA Cup")[21] The rebuilding
process meant that between 2001 and 2006 they were hosted at the [Millennium
Stadium](/wiki/Millennium_Stadium "Millennium Stadium") in
[Cardiff](/wiki/Cardiff "Cardiff") in Wales. Prior to rebuilding, the final
was hosted by the [original Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\)
"Wembley Stadium \(1923\)") since it opened in
[1923](/wiki/1922%E2%80%9323_FA_Cup "1922–23 FA Cup") (being originally named
the Empire Stadium). One exception to this 78 year series of Empire Stadium
finals (including five replays) was the [1970 replay](/wiki/1970_FA_Cup_Final
"1970 FA Cup Final") between Leeds and Chelsea, held at [Old
Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford "Old Trafford") in Manchester.

In the 51 years prior to the Empire Stadium opening, the final (including 8
replays) was held in a variety of locations, predominantly in London, and
mainly at the [Kennington Oval](/wiki/The_Oval "The Oval") and then [Crystal
Palace](/wiki/Crystal_Palace_National_Sports_Centre#Crystal_Palace_FA_Cup_Finals_1895.E2.80.931914
"Crystal Palace National Sports Centre"). It was played 22 times at The Oval
(the inaugural competition in 1872, and then all but two times until 1892).
After The Oval, Crystal Palace hosted 21 finals from 1895 to 1914, broken up
by 4 four replays elsewhere. The other London venues were [Stamford
Bridge](/wiki/Stamford_Bridge_\(stadium\) "Stamford Bridge \(stadium\)") from
1920 to 1922 (the last three finals before the move to Empire Stadium); and
the University of Oxford's [Lillie Bridge](/wiki/Lillie_Bridge_Grounds "Lillie
Bridge Grounds") in [Fulham](/wiki/Fulham "Fulham") for the second ever final,
in 1873. The other venues used sparingly in this period were all outside of
London, as follows:

  * [Racecourse Ground,](/wiki/County_Cricket_Ground,_Derby "County Cricket Ground, Derby") Derby (1886)
  * [Fallowfield Stadium](/wiki/Fallowfield_Stadium "Fallowfield Stadium"), Manchester (1893)
  * [Goodison Park](/wiki/Goodison_Park "Goodison Park"), Liverpool (1894)
  * [Burnden Park](/wiki/Burnden_Park "Burnden Park"), [Bolton](/wiki/Bolton "Bolton") (1901 replay)
  * [Old Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford "Old Trafford"), Manchester (1911 replay)
  * Goodison Park (1910 replay)
  * [Bramall Lane](/wiki/Bramall_Lane "Bramall Lane"), Sheffield (1912 replay)
  * Old Trafford (1915)

### Artificial turf[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Artificial turf")]

The FA permitted [artificial turf](/wiki/Artificial_turf "Artificial turf")
(3G) pitches in all rounds of the competition from the [2014–15
edition](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_FA_Cup "2014–15 FA Cup") and beyond.[22] Under
the 2015–16 rules, the pitch must be of FIFA One Star quality, or Two Star for
ties if they involve one of the 92 professional clubs.[2] This followed
approval two years previously for their use in the qualifying rounds only – if
a team with a 3G pitch progressed to the competition proper, they had to
switch their tie to the ground of another eligible entrant with a natural
grass pitch.[23] Having been strong proponents of the surface, the first match
in the proper rounds to be played on a 3G surface was a televised first round
replay at Maidstone United's [Gallagher Stadium](/wiki/Gallagher_Stadium
"Gallagher Stadium") on 20 November 2015.[24]

## Trophy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Trophy")]

The eventual winners of the competition receive the FA Cup; it is only loaned
to the club by the FA, under the current (2015–16) rules it must be returned
by March 1, or earlier if given seven days’ notice.[2] Traditionally, the
holders had the Cup until the following year's presentation, although more
recently the trophy has been taken on publicity tours by the FA in between
finals.[25]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/The_King_George_V_presents_the_FA_Cup_1914.jpg/250px-
The_King_George_V_presents_the_FA_Cup_1914.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_King_George_V_presents_the_FA_Cup_1914.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_King_George_V_presents_the_FA_Cup_1914.jpg "Enlarge")

King [George V](/wiki/George_V "George V") presents the FA Cup trophy to Tommy
Boyle of [Burnley F.C.](/wiki/Burnley_F.C. "Burnley F.C."), April 1914

The trophy comes in three parts – the cup itself, plus a lid and a base. There
have been two designs of trophy in use, but five physical trophies have been
presented. The original trophy, known as the "little tin idol", was 18 inches
high and made by Martin, Hall & Co. It was stolen in 1895 and never recovered,
and so was replaced by an exact replica, used until 1910. The FA decided to
change the design after the 1909 winners, Manchester United, made their own
replica, leading the FA to realise they did not own the copyright.[26] This
new, larger design was by [Fattorini and Sons](/wiki/Fattorini_and_Sons
"Fattorini and Sons"), and was used from 1911.[26] In order to preserve this
original, from 1992 it was replaced by an exact replica, although this had to
be replaced after just over two decades, after showing wear and tear from
being handled more than in previous eras. This third replica, first used in
2014, was built heavier to withstand the increased handling.[25] Of the four
surviving trophies, only the 1895 replica has entered private ownership.[27]

The name of the winning team is engraved on the silver band around the base as
soon as the final has finished, in order to be ready in time for the
presentation ceremony.[25] This means the engraver has just five minutes to
perform a task which would take 20 under normal conditions, although time is
saved by engraving the year on during the match, and sketching the presumed
winner.[28] During the final, the trophy is decorated with ribbons in the
colours of both finalists, with the loser's ribbons being removed at the end
of the game.[29] The tradition of tying ribbons started after [Tottenham
Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C.") won the [1901
FA Cup Final](/wiki/1901_FA_Cup_Final "1901 FA Cup Final") and the wife of a
Spurs director decided to tie blue and white ribbons to the handles of the
cup.[30] Traditionally, at Wembley finals, the presentation is made at the
Royal Box, with players, led by the captain, mounting a staircase to a gangway
in front of the box and returning by a second staircase on the other side of
the box. At Cardiff the presentation was made on a podium on the pitch.

The tradition of presenting the trophy immediately after the game did not
start until the [1882 final](/wiki/1882_FA_Cup_Final "1882 FA Cup Final");
after the first final in 1872 the trophy was not presented to the winners,
Wanderers, until a reception held four weeks later in the Pall Mall Restaurant
in London.[31] Under the original rules, the trophy was to be permanently
presented to any club which won the competition three times, although when
inaugural winners Wanderers achieved this feat by the [1876
final](/wiki/1876_FA_Cup_Final "1876 FA Cup Final"), the rules were changed by
FA Secretary CW Alcock (who was also captain of Wanderers in their first
victory).[32]

### Original design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Original design")]

#### 1871 original[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: 1871 original")]

The first trophy, the 'little tin idol', was made by Martin, Hall & Co at a
cost of £20[33] It was stolen from a [Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham
"Birmingham") shoe shop window belonging to William Shillcock while held by
[Aston Villa](/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C. "Aston Villa F.C.") on 11 September 1895
and was never seen again. Despite a £10 reward for information, the crime was
never solved. As it happened while it was in their care, the FA fined Villa
£25 to pay for a replacement.

Just over 60 years later, 80 year old career criminal Henry (Harry) James
Burge claimed to have committed the theft, confessing to a newspaper, with the
story being published in the _[Sunday Pictorial](/wiki/Sunday_Pictorial
"Sunday Pictorial")_ newspaper on 23 February 1958. He claimed to have carried
out the robbery with two other men, although when discrepancies with a
contemporaneous report in the _[Birmingham Post](/wiki/Birmingham_Post
"Birmingham Post")_ newspaper (the crime pre-dated written police reports) in
his account of the means of entry and other items stolen, detectives decided
there was no realistic possibility of a conviction and the case was closed.
Burge claimed the cup had been melted down to make counterfeit [half-
crown](/wiki/Half_crown_\(British_coin\) "Half crown \(British coin\)") coins,
which matched known intelligence of the time, in which stolen silver was being
used to forge coins which were then laundered through [betting
shops](/wiki/Betting_shops "Betting shops") at a local racecourse, although
Burge had no past history of forgery in a record of 42 previous convictions
for which he had spent 42 years in prison. He had been further imprisoned in
1957 for seven years for theft from cars. Released in 1961, he died in
1964.[34]

#### 1895 replica[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: 1895 replica")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/1896_FA_Cup.jpg/170px-1896_FA_Cup.jpg)](/wiki/File:1896_FA_Cup.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1896_FA_Cup.jpg "Enlarge")

The second FA Cup trophy, used between 1896 and 1910.

After being rendered obsolete by the redesign, the 1895 replica was presented
in 1910 to the FA's long-serving president [Lord
Kinnaird](/wiki/Arthur_Fitzgerald_Kinnaird,_11th_Lord_Kinnaird "Arthur
Fitzgerald Kinnaird, 11th Lord Kinnaird").[26] Kinnaird died in 1923, and his
family kept it in their possession, out of view, until putting it up for
auction in 2005.[35] It was duly sold at [Christie's](/wiki/Christie%27s
"Christie's") auction house on 19 May 2005 for [£](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound
sterling")420,000 (£478,400 including auction fees and taxes).[26] The sale
price set a new world record for a piece of football
[memorabilia](/wiki/Souvenir "Souvenir"), surpassing the £254,000 paid for the
[Jules Rimet World Cup Trophy](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Trophy "FIFA World Cup
Trophy") in 1997.[27] The successful bidder was [David
Gold](/wiki/David_Gold_\(businessman\) "David Gold \(businessman\)"), the then
joint chairman of [Birmingham City](/wiki/Birmingham_City_F.C. "Birmingham
City F.C."); claiming the FA and government were doing nothing proactive to
ensure the trophy remained in the country, Gold stated his purchase was
motivated by wanting to save it for the nation.[27] Accordingly, Gold
presented the trophy to the [National Football
Museum](/wiki/National_Football_Museum "National Football Museum") in Preston
on 20 April 2006, where it went on immediate public display.[35] It later
moved with the museum to its new location in Manchester.[26] In November 2012,
it was ceremonially presented to [Royal
Engineers](/wiki/Royal_Engineers_A.F.C. "Royal Engineers A.F.C."), after they
beat [Wanderers](/wiki/Wanderers_F.C. "Wanderers F.C.") 7–1 in a charity
replay of the [first FA Cup final](/wiki/1872_FA_Cup_Final "1872 FA Cup
Final").[36]

### Current design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Current design")]

#### 1911 original[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: 1911 original")]

The redesigned trophy first used in 1911 was larger at 61.5 cm (24.2 inches)
high, and was designed and manufactured by [Fattorini's of
Bradford](/wiki/Messers_Fattorini_and_Sons "Messers Fattorini and Sons"),
coincidentally being won by [Bradford City](/wiki/Bradford_City_A.F.C.
"Bradford City A.F.C.") in its first outing.[25][26]

On the 27 March 2016 episode of the BBC television program [Antiques
Roadshow](/wiki/Antiques_Roadshow "Antiques Roadshow"), this trophy was valued
at £1 million by expert [Alastair Dickenson](/wiki/Alastair_Dickenson
"Alastair Dickenson"), although he suggested that, due to the design featuring
depictions of grapes and vines, it may not have been specifically produced for
the FA, but was instead an off the shelf design originally meant to be a wine
or champagne cooler.[26]

A smaller, but otherwise identical replica was also made by Fattorini, the
North Wales Coast FA Cup trophy, and is contested annually by members of that
regional Association.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

#### 1992 replica[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: 1992 replica")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/The_FA_Cup_Trophy.jpg/170px-
The_FA_Cup_Trophy.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_FA_Cup_Trophy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_FA_Cup_Trophy.jpg "Enlarge")

The current design of the FA Cup (1992 replica pictured)

The 1992 replica was made by [Toye, Kenning and
Spencer](/wiki/Toye,_Kenning_and_Spencer "Toye, Kenning and Spencer").[37] A
copy of this trophy was also produced, in case anything happened to the
primary trophy.[38]

#### 2014 replica[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: 2014 replica")]

The 2014 replica was made by [Thomas Lyte](/wiki/Thomas_Lyte "Thomas Lyte"),
handcrafted in sterling 925 silver over 250 hours. A weight increase to
increase durability has taken it to 6.3 kilograms (14 lb).[25]

## Medals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=24 "Edit
section: Medals")]

Each club in the final receives 30 winners or runners-up medals to be
distributed among players, staff, and officials.[39]

In 1914 [Burnley](/wiki/Burnley_F.C. "Burnley F.C.") won the cup and received
unique medals incorrectly struck as "English Cup Winners". One is displayed at
[Turf Moor](/wiki/Turf_Moor "Turf Moor"), within the 1914 collection.[40]

## Sponsorship[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Sponsorship")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/2010_FA_Cup_Final_banner.jpg/250px-2010_FA_Cup_Final_banner.jpg)](/wiki/File:2010_FA_Cup_Final_banner.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2010_FA_Cup_Final_banner.jpg "Enlarge")

Pre-match ceremony of [2010 FA Cup Final](/wiki/2010_FA_Cup_Final "2010 FA Cup
Final") showing sponsorship by [E.ON](/wiki/E.ON "E.ON")

See also: [English football sponsorship](/wiki/English_football_sponsorship
"English football sponsorship")

Since the start of the 1994–95 season, the FA Cup has been sponsored. However,
to protect the identity of the competition, the sponsored name has always
included 'The FA Cup' in addition to the sponsor's name, unlike sponsorship
deals for the [League Cup](/wiki/EFL_Cup "EFL Cup") where the word 'cup' is
preceded by only the sponsor's name. Sponsorship deals run for four years,
though – as in the case of E.ON – one-year extensions may be agreed. [Emirates
airline](/wiki/Emirates_\(airline\) "Emirates \(airline\)") is the sponsor
from 2015 to 2018, renaming the competition as 'The Emirates FA Cup', unlike
previous editions, which included 'The FA Cup in association with E.ON' and
'The FA Cup with Budweiser'.[41]

---|---|---  
1871/72–1993/94 | No main sponsor | **The FA Cup**

1998/99–2001/02 | [![France](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png)](/wiki/France "France") [AXA](/wiki/AXA "AXA") | **The AXA-Sponsored FA Cup**[43]  
2002/03–2005/06 | No main sponsor | **The FA Cup**  
2006/07–2010/11 | [![Germany](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png)](/wiki/Germany "Germany") [E.ON](/wiki/E.ON "E.ON") | **The FA Cup sponsored by E.ON**[44][45]  
2011/12–2013/14 | [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Budweiser](/wiki/Budweiser "Budweiser") | **The FA Cup with Budweiser**[46]

From August 2006 to 2013, [Umbro](/wiki/Umbro "Umbro") supplied match balls
for all FA Cup matches. Since March 2013, [Nike](/wiki/Nike_Inc. "Nike Inc.")
has supplied the official match ball.[47]

## Cup runs and giant
killings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=31 "Edit
section: Cup runs and giant killings")]

The possibility of unlikely victories in the earlier rounds of the
competition, where lower ranked teams beat higher placed opposition in what is
known as a "giant killing", is much anticipated by the public. Such upsets are
considered an integral part of the tradition and prestige of the competition,
and the attention gained by giant-killing teams can be as great as that for
winners of the cup.[54] Almost every club in the [League
Pyramid](/wiki/English_football_league_system "English football league
system") has a fondly remembered giant-killing act in its history.[55][56] It
is considered particularly newsworthy when a top [Premier
League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League") team suffers an upset defeat,
or where the giant-killer is a non-league club, i.e. from outside the
professional levels of [The Football League](/wiki/The_Football_League "The
Football League").

One analysis of four years of FA Cup results showed that it was 99.85 per cent
likely that at least one team would beat one from its next higher division in
a given year. The probability drops to 48.8 per cent for a two-division gap,
and 39.28 per cent for a three-division gap.[55]

### Early years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=32 "Edit
section: Early years")]

[The Football League](/wiki/The_Football_League "The Football League") was
founded in 1888, 16 years after the first FA Cup competition. Since the
creation of The Football League, [Tottenham
Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C.") is the only
non-league "giant-killer" to win the Cup, taking the [1901 FA
Cup](/wiki/1901_FA_Cup_Final "1901 FA Cup Final") with a victory over
[reigning](/wiki/1899%E2%80%931900_Football_League "1899–1900 Football
League") league runners-up [Sheffield United](/wiki/Sheffield_United_F.C.
"Sheffield United F.C."): although at that time, there were only two divisions
and 36 clubs in the Football League, and Spurs were champions of the next
strongest football league – the Southern League and probably already good
enough for the First Division (as was shown when they joined the Second
Division in 1908 and immediately won promotion to the First.) Only two other
actual non-League clubs have even reached the final since the founding of the
League: Sheffield Wednesday in 1890 (champions of the Football Alliance, a
rival league which was already effectively the Second Division, which it
formally became in 1892 – Wednesday being let straight into the First
Division), and [Southampton](/wiki/Southampton_F.C. "Southampton F.C.") in
1900 and 1902 (in which years they were also Southern League champions,
proving the strength of that league: again, they were probably of equivalent
standard to a First Division club at the time, but Southampton's form
subsequently faded and they did not join the League till 1920 and the
formation of the Third Division.)

### Non-league giant
killings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Non-league giant killings")]

The most recent examples of a [non-league](/wiki/Non-league "Non-league") team
([Levels 5 to 10](/wiki/English_football_league_system#The_System "English
football league system")) beating a Level 1 opponent are [National
League](/wiki/National_League_\(division\) "National League \(division\)")
side [Lincoln City](/wiki/Lincoln_City_F.C. "Lincoln City F.C.")'s [away
victory](/wiki/Burnley_0%E2%80%931_Lincoln_City_\(2017\) "Burnley 0–1 Lincoln
City \(2017\)") over Premier League side [Burnley](/wiki/Burnley_F.C. "Burnley
F.C.") in the [2016–17 FA Cup](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_FA_Cup "2016–17 FA Cup")
and [Conference Premier](/wiki/Conference_Premier "Conference Premier") side
[Luton Town](/wiki/Luton_Town_F.C. "Luton Town F.C.")'s [away
victory](/wiki/Norwich_City_0%E2%80%931_Luton_Town_\(2013\) "Norwich City 0–1
Luton Town \(2013\)") over Level 1 [Premier
League](/wiki/English_Premier_League "English Premier League")'s [Norwich
City](/wiki/Norwich_City_F.C. "Norwich City F.C.") in the [2012–13 Fourth
Round Proper](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_FA_Cup#Fourth_Round_Proper "2012–13 FA
Cup"). Prior to that game, the last time a non-league side defeated a Level 1
club was in 1989 when [Sutton United](/wiki/Sutton_United_F.C. "Sutton United
F.C.") claimed a [2–1
victory](/wiki/Sutton_United_2%E2%80%931_Coventry_City_\(1989\) "Sutton United
2–1 Coventry City \(1989\)") at home over [Coventry
City](/wiki/Coventry_City_F.C. "Coventry City F.C."), who had won the FA Cup
less than two years prior.[57]

In the [1971–72 FA Cup](/wiki/1971%E2%80%9372_FA_Cup "1971–72 FA Cup"), a non-
league side achieved a Level 1 giant killing that was voted "best FA Cup tie
ever" in a 2007 poll by _[The Observer](/wiki/The_Observer "The Observer")_
newspaper.[58] Non-league [Hereford United](/wiki/Hereford_United "Hereford
United") was trailing First Division [Newcastle United](/wiki/Newcastle_United
"Newcastle United") 0–1 with less than seven minutes left in the [Third Round
Proper replay](/wiki/1971%E2%80%9372_FA_Cup#Third_Round_Proper "1971–72 FA
Cup"), when Hereford's Ronnie Radford scored the equalizer – a goal still
shown regularly when FA Cup fixtures are broadcast. Hereford finished the
shocking comeback by defeating Newcastle 2–1 in the match.

Some small clubs gain a reputation for being "cup specialists" after two or
more giant killing feats within a few years.[55] [Yeovil
Town](/wiki/Yeovil_Town_F.C. "Yeovil Town F.C.") holds the record for the most
victories over league opposition as a non-league team, having recorded 20 wins
through the years before it achieved
[promotion](/wiki/Promotion_and_relegation#English_example "Promotion and
relegation") into The Football League.[59] The record for a club which has
never entered The Football League is held by
[Altrincham](/wiki/Altrincham_F.C. "Altrincham F.C."), with 16 wins against
league teams.

### Non-league cup
runs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section:
Non-league cup runs")]

See also: [List of non-league clubs in the Fifth Round of the FA Cup since
1945](/wiki/List_of_non-
league_clubs_in_the_Fifth_Round_of_the_FA_Cup_since_1945 "List of non-league
clubs in the Fifth Round of the FA Cup since 1945")

For non-league teams, reaching the Third Round Proper – where all Level 1
sides now enter – is considered a major achievement. In the [2008–09 FA
Cup](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_FA_Cup "2008–09 FA Cup"), a record nine non-league
teams achieved this feat.[60] As of the 2016–17 season, only nine non-league
teams have [reached the Fifth Round Proper](/wiki/List_of_non-
league_clubs_in_the_Fifth_Round_of_the_FA_Cup_since_1945 "List of non-league
clubs in the Fifth Round of the FA Cup since 1945") (final 16) since 1945,[61]
and only [Lincoln City](/wiki/Lincoln_City_F.C. "Lincoln City F.C.") have
progressed to the Sixth Round (final 8), during the 2016–17 edition of the
tournament.[62]

[Chasetown](/wiki/Chasetown_F.C. "Chasetown F.C."), while playing at [Level
8](/wiki/English_football_league_system#The_system "English football league
system") of English football during the [2007–08
competition](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_FA_Cup "2007–08 FA Cup"), are the lowest-
ranked team to ever play in the Third Round Proper (final 64, of 731 teams
entered that season). Chasetown was then a member of the [Southern League
Division One Midlands](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_Southern_Football_League "2007–08
Southern Football League") (a lower level within the [Southern Football
League](/wiki/Southern_Football_League "Southern Football League")), when they
lost to [Football League Championship](/wiki/Football_League_Championship
"Football League Championship") (Level 2) team [Cardiff
City](/wiki/Cardiff_City_F.C. "Cardiff City F.C."), the eventual FA Cup
runners-up that year.[63] Their success earned the lowly organisation over
£60,000 in prize money.

### Giant killings between league
clubs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section:
Giant killings between league clubs")]

In games between league sides, one of the most notable results was the [1992
victory](/wiki/1991%E2%80%9392_FA_Cup#Third_round_proper "1991–92 FA Cup") by
[Wrexham](/wiki/Wrexham_F.C. "Wrexham F.C."),
[92nd/last](/wiki/1990%E2%80%9391_Football_League#Fourth_Division "1990–91
Football League") in the previous season's league, over
[reigning](/wiki/1990%E2%80%9391_Football_League#First_Division "1990–91
Football League") league champion Arsenal. Another similar shock was when
[Shrewsbury Town](/wiki/Shrewsbury_Town_F.C. "Shrewsbury Town F.C.") beat
[Everton](/wiki/Everton_F.C. "Everton F.C.") 2–1 in 2003. Everton finished 7th
in The Premier League and Shrewsbury Town were relegated to the Football
Conference that same season.

## Winners and
finalists[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=36 "Edit
section: Winners and finalists")]

Main article: [FA Cup Final](/wiki/FA_Cup_Final "FA Cup Final")

See also: [List of FA Cup finals](/wiki/List_of_FA_Cup_finals "List of FA Cup
finals")

### Consecutive
winners[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section:
Consecutive winners")]

Four clubs have won consecutive FA Cups on more than one occasion:
[Wanderers](/wiki/Wanderers_F.C. "Wanderers F.C.") (1872, 1873 and 1876, 1877,
1878), [Blackburn Rovers](/wiki/Blackburn_Rovers_F.C. "Blackburn Rovers F.C.")
(1884, 1885, 1886 and 1890, 1891), [Tottenham
Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C.") (1961, 1962
and 1981, 1982) and [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.")
([2002](/wiki/2002_FA_Cup_Final "2002 FA Cup Final"),
[2003](/wiki/2003_FA_Cup_Final "2003 FA Cup Final") and
[2014](/wiki/2014_FA_Cup_Final "2014 FA Cup Final"),
[2015](/wiki/2015_FA_Cup_Final "2015 FA Cup Final")).

### Winning managers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: Winning managers")]

See also: [List of FA Cup winning
managers](/wiki/List_of_FA_Cup_winning_managers "List of FA Cup winning
managers")

The record for most winner's medals for a manager is held by [Arsène
Wenger](/wiki/Ars%C3%A8ne_Wenger "Arsène Wenger"), who has won seven titles
with Arsenal ([1998](/wiki/1998_FA_Cup_Final "1998 FA Cup Final"),
[2002](/wiki/2002_FA_Cup_Final "2002 FA Cup Final"),
[2003](/wiki/2003_FA_Cup_Final "2003 FA Cup Final"),
[2005](/wiki/2005_FA_Cup_Final "2005 FA Cup Final"),
[2014](/wiki/2014_FA_Cup_Final "2014 FA Cup Final"),
[2015](/wiki/2015_FA_Cup_Final "2015 FA Cup Final"),
[2017](/wiki/2017_FA_Cup_Final "2017 FA Cup Final")).[64]

### Doubles/Trebles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: Doubles/Trebles")]

Seven clubs have won the FA Cup as part of a [League and Cup
double](/wiki/Double_\(association_football\) "Double \(association
football\)"), namely [Preston North End](/wiki/Preston_North_End_F.C. "Preston
North End F.C.") (1889), [Aston Villa](/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C. "Aston Villa
F.C.") (1897), [Tottenham Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham
Hotspur F.C.") (1961), [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.") (1971,
1998, 2002), [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C.") (1986),
[Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.")
(1994, 1996, 1999) and [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.") (2010). In
1993, Arsenal became the first side to win both the FA Cup and the [League
Cup](/wiki/EFL_Cup "EFL Cup") in the same season when they beat [Sheffield
Wednesday](/wiki/Sheffield_Wednesday_F.C. "Sheffield Wednesday F.C.") 2–1 in
both finals. Liverpool (in 2001) and Chelsea (in 2007) have since repeated
this feat. In 2012, Chelsea accomplished a different cup double consisting of
the FA Cup and the [2012](/wiki/2012_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2012 UEFA
Champions League Final") [Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA
Champions League"). In [1998–99](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_in_English_football
"1998–99 in English football"), Manchester United added the
[1999](/wiki/1999_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1999 UEFA Champions League
Final") [Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions
League") title to their league and cup double to complete a unique
[Treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\) "Treble \(association
football\)"). Two years later, in
[2000–01](/wiki/2000%E2%80%9301_in_English_football "2000–01 in English
football"), Liverpool won the FA Cup, [League Cup](/wiki/EFL_Cup "EFL Cup")
and [UEFA Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League") to complete a
[cup treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\)#Other_trebles "Treble
\(association football\)"). An English Treble has never been achieved.

### Outside England[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=40
"Edit section: Outside England")]

The FA Cup has only been won by a non-English team once. [Cardiff
City](/wiki/Cardiff_City_F.C. "Cardiff City F.C.") achieved this in 1927 when
they beat Arsenal in the final at Wembley. They had previously made it to the
final only to lose to [Sheffield United](/wiki/Sheffield_United_F.C.
"Sheffield United F.C.") in 1925 and lost another final to
[Portsmouth](/wiki/Portsmouth_F.C. "Portsmouth F.C.") in 2008. Cardiff City is
also the only team to win the national cups of two different countries in the
same season, having also won the [Welsh Cup](/wiki/Welsh_Cup "Welsh Cup") in
1927. The Scottish team [Queen's Park](/wiki/Queen%27s_Park_F.C. "Queen's Park
F.C.") reached and lost the final in both 1884 and 1885.

### Outside the top
division[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=41 "Edit
section: Outside the top division")]

Since the creation of the Football League in 1888, the final has never been
contested by two teams from outside the top division, and there have only been
eight winners who were not in the top flight: [Notts
County](/wiki/Notts_County_F.C. "Notts County F.C.")
([1894](/wiki/1894_FA_Cup_Final "1894 FA Cup Final")); [Tottenham
Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C.")
([1901](/wiki/1901_FA_Cup_Final "1901 FA Cup Final")); [Wolverhampton
Wanderers](/wiki/Wolverhampton_Wanderers_F.C. "Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.")
([1908](/wiki/1908_FA_Cup_Final "1908 FA Cup Final"));
[Barnsley](/wiki/Barnsley_F.C. "Barnsley F.C.")
([1912](/wiki/1912_FA_Cup_Final "1912 FA Cup Final")); [West Bromwich
Albion](/wiki/West_Bromwich_Albion_F.C. "West Bromwich Albion F.C.")
([1931](/wiki/1931_FA_Cup_Final "1931 FA Cup Final"));
[Sunderland](/wiki/Sunderland_A.F.C. "Sunderland A.F.C.")
([1973](/wiki/1973_FA_Cup_Final "1973 FA Cup Final")),
[Southampton](/wiki/Southampton_F.C. "Southampton F.C.")
([1976](/wiki/1976_FA_Cup_Final "1976 FA Cup Final")) and [West Ham
United](/wiki/West_Ham_United_F.C. "West Ham United F.C.")
([1980](/wiki/1980_FA_Cup_Final "1980 FA Cup Final")). With the exception of
Tottenham, these clubs were all playing in the second tier (the old [Second
Division](/wiki/Football_League_Second_Division "Football League Second
Division")) – Tottenham were playing in the [Southern
League](/wiki/Southern_Football_League "Southern Football League") and were
only elected to the Football League in 1908, meaning they are the only non-
League winners of the FA Cup since the League's creation. Other than
Tottenham's victory, only 24 finalists have come from outside English
football's top tier, with a record of 7 wins and 17 runners-up: and none at
all from the third tier or lower, Southampton ([1902](/wiki/1902_FA_Cup_Final
"1902 FA Cup Final"), then in the Southern League) being the last finalist
from outside the top two tiers.

Sunderland's win in 1973 was considered a major upset, having beaten [Leeds
United](/wiki/Leeds_United_F.C. "Leeds United F.C.") who finished third in the
top flight that season.[65] Uniquely, in [2008](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_FA_Cup
"2007–08 FA Cup") three of the four semi-finalists (Barnsley, [Cardiff
City](/wiki/Cardiff_City_F.C. "Cardiff City F.C.") and West Bromwich) were
from outside the top division, although the eventual winner was the last
remaining top-flight team, [Portsmouth](/wiki/Portsmouth_F.C. "Portsmouth
F.C.").[66] West Bromwich (1931) are the only team to have won the FA Cup and
earned promotion to the top flight in the same season; whereas [Wigan
Athletic](/wiki/Wigan_Athletic_F.C. "Wigan Athletic F.C.")
([2013](/wiki/2013_FA_Cup_Final "2013 FA Cup Final")) are the only team to
have won the Cup and been relegated from the top flight in the same season.

## Media coverage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=42
"Edit section: Media coverage")]

### Domestic
broadcasters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=FA_Cup&action=edit&section=43 "Edit
section: Domestic broadcasters")]

See also: [English football on
television](/wiki/English_football_on_television "English football on
television")

The FA Cup Final is one of 10 events reserved for live broadcast on UK
terrestrial television under the [Ofcom Code on Sports and Other Listed and
Designated
Events](/wiki/Ofcom_Code_on_Sports_and_Other_Listed_and_Designated_Events
"Ofcom Code on Sports and Other Listed and Designated Events").

In the early years of coverage the BBC had exclusive radio coverage with a
picture of the pitch marked in the Radio Times with numbered squares to help
the listener follow the match on the radio. The first FA Cup Final on Radio
was in 1926 between Bolton Wanderers and Manchester City but this was only
broadcast in Manchester, the first national final on BBC Radio was between
Arsenal and Cardiff in 1927. The first final on BBC Television was in 1937 in
a match which featured Sunderland and Preston North End but this was not
televised in full. The following season's final between Preston and
Huddersfield was covered in full by the BBC. When ITV was formed in 1955 they
shared final coverage with the BBC in one of the only club matches shown live
on television, during the 1970s and 1980s coverage became more elaborate with
BBC and ITV trying to steal viewers from the others by starting coverage
earlier and earlier some starting as early as 9 a.m. which was six hours
before kick off. Nowadays, this continues with Setanta and ESPN having all-day
broadcasts from Wembley, but terrestrial TV coverage usually begins two hours
before kick off. The sharing of rights between BBC and ITV continued from 1955
to 1988, when ITV lost coverage to the new Sports Channel which later became
[Sky Sports](/wiki/Sky_Sports "Sky Sports").

From 1988 to 1997, the BBC and Sky Sports had coverage of the FA Cup, the BBC
had highlights on Match of the Day and usually one match per round while Sky
had the same deal. From 1997 to 2001, ITV and Sky shared live coverage with
both having two matches per round and BBC continuing with highlights on Match
of the Day. From 2002 to 2008, BBC and Sky again shared coverage with BBC
having two or three matches per round and Sky having one or two. From
[2008–09](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_FA_Cup "2008–09 FA Cup") to
[2013–14](/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_FA_Cup "2013–14 FA Cup"), FA Cup matches are
shown live by [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_channel\) "ITV \(TV channel\)") across
England and [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales"), with [UTV](/wiki/UTV_\(TV_channel\)
"UTV \(TV channel\)") broadcasting to [Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland "Northern Ireland") but STV refusing to show
them. ITV shows 16 FA Cup games per season, including the first pick of live
matches from each of the first to sixth rounds of the competition, plus one
semi-final exclusively live. The final is also shown live on ITV. Under the
same 2008 contract, [Setanta Sports](/wiki/Setanta_Sports "Setanta Sports")
showed three games and one replay in each round from round three to five, two
quarter-finals, one semi-final and the final. The channel also broadcast ITV's
matches exclusively to [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"), after the ITV
franchise holder in Scotland, [STV](/wiki/STV_\(TV_network\) "STV \(TV
network\)"), decided not to broadcast FA Cup games. Setanta entered
administration in June 2009 and as a result the FA terminated Setanta's deal
to broadcast FA-sanctioned competitions and [England
internationals](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national
football team").[67] As a result of Setanta going out of business ITV showed
the competition exclusively in the 2009–10 season with between three and four
matches per round, all quarter finals, semi-finals and final live as the FA
could not find a pay TV broadcaster in time. ESPN bought the competition for
the 2010–11 to 2012–13 season and during this time Rebecca Lowe became the
first woman to host the FA Cup Final in the UK.

In October 2009, The FA announced that ITV would show an additional match in
the First and Second Rounds on ITV, with one replay match shown on
[ITV4](/wiki/ITV4 "ITV4"). One match and one replay match from the first two
rounds will broadcast on The FA website for free, in a similar situation to
the [2010 World Cup
Qualifier](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(UEFA\) "2010 FIFA World
Cup qualification \(UEFA\)") between
[Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine_national_football_team "Ukraine national football
team") and [England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England national
football team").[68] The 2009–10 First Round match between [Oldham
Athletic](/wiki/Oldham_Athletic_A.F.C. "Oldham Athletic A.F.C.") and [Leeds
United](/wiki/Leeds_United_A.F.C. "Leeds United A.F.C.") was the first FA Cup
match to be streamed online live.[69]

Many[_[who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] expected [BSkyB](/wiki/BSkyB
"BSkyB") to make a bid to show some of the remaining FA Cup games for the
remainder of the 2009–10 season which would include a semi-final and shared
rights to the final.[70] [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN_\(UK\) "ESPN \(UK\)") took over the
package Setanta held for the FA Cup from the 2010–11 season.[71] The 2011
final was also shown live on [Sky 3D](/wiki/Sky_3D "Sky 3D") in addition to
ESPN (who provided the 3D coverage for Sky 3D) and ITV.[72] Following the sale
of ESPN's UK and Ireland channels to [BT](/wiki/BT_Group "BT Group"), ESPN's
rights package transferred to [BT Sport](/wiki/BT_Sport "BT Sport") from the
2013–14 season.[73]

[BBC Radio 5 Live](/wiki/BBC_Radio_5_Live "BBC Radio 5 Live") and
[Talksport](/wiki/Talksport "Talksport") provides radio coverage including
several full live commentaries per round, with additional commentaries
broadcast on [BBC Local Radio](/wiki/BBC_Local_Radio "BBC Local Radio").

Until the 2008–09 season, the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") and [Sky
Sports](/wiki/Sky_Sports "Sky Sports") shared television coverage, with the
BBC showing three matches in the earlier rounds. Some analysts argued the
decision to move away from the Sky and, in particular, the BBC undermined the
FA Cup in the eyes of the public.[74]

The early rounds of the 2008–09 competition were covered for the first time by
ITV's online service, [ITV Local](/wiki/ITV_Local "ITV Local"). The first
match of the competition, between Wantage Town and Brading Town, was broadcast
live online. Highlights of eight games of each round were broadcast as catch
up on ITV Local.[75][76] Since ITV Local closed, this coverage did not
continue.

ITV lost the rights to the FA Cup beginning with the [2014–15 FA
Cup](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_FA_Cup "2014–15 FA Cup"), terrestrial rights will
return to [BBC Sport](/wiki/BBC_Sport "BBC Sport"), with the final being shown
on [BBC One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One") while BT Sport hold the pay TV rights.
Under this deal, the BBC will show around the same number of games as ITV and
still having the first pick for each round.[77]

Matches involving Welsh clubs are sometimes exclusively broadcast on [Welsh
language](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") channel [S4C](/wiki/S4C
"S4C"), which is also available to view across the rest of the United Kingdom
on satellite and cable television, and through the channel's website.[78] A
similar arrangement is shared with [BBC Cymru Wales](/wiki/BBC_Cymru_Wales
"BBC Cymru Wales") from 2014–15, potentially giving the BBC an extra match per
round.[79]

qa.question: when do league one teams enter the fa cup

nq_294047_3.Query Analysis: The query asks for the specific time or round when teams from League One enter the FA Cup competition.
nq_294047_3.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that League One teams enter the FA Cup in January.
nq_294047_3.Document Content Analysis: The document provides an overview of the FA Cup tournament structure, including the rounds and the entry points for different league levels. It mentions that the first six rounds are the Qualifying Competition, and 32 teams progress to the first round of the Competition Proper, meeting the first of the 48 professional teams from Leagues One and Two. The last entrants are the Premier League and Championship clubs in the Third Round Proper.
nq_294047_3.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Leagues One' and 'FA Cup', which are directly related to the query.
